Lima, Julio 13ce de 1916
Dear Laura:
div1.p:
We leave Lima tomorrow afternoon
-or Saturday morning -(day after tomorrow). I think
the latter is most probable. Will reach Colon
7 days later - We will go through the Canal to
Colon, because our Quarantine, for plague, is first
over until 7 days. Hence we reach Colon on
the 21 or 22 & Panama, where I may meet
little Laura, the same day.

It is cold here, no fires no fire places. I am the
only one who does not mind it, & I have on
2 shirts of underwear. If I were going fur-
ther on this trip - I would get me a heavy
overcoat, which would much in my way
in the journey from Rio northward.

However we go no further southward, & it
will be but wit, enough from Panama on,
I would have liked & have taken the
trip from Mallendo up to Lake Titicaca & Cuz-
co, & La Paz, I was so perfectly comfortable
enroute to Q Quito nearly 12,000 at one point
(11.869). I do not believe that the 14600 feet would
have affected me. That is only one pass one of
13.900
2
but the hard part of the Journey - 3 1/2 days
of stage, is from 9000' down to 6500'6.
However, we are not going.

I can't see why I feel so badly aboard ship
I am not sea-sick - but headachy & indigestion
It is not the cold for the worst was from N. Y. to
Colon nor the heat for it was bad from the
2d day from Guayaquil to with in 12 hours
of Lima. Am feeling well now. All signs of my
functional Cardiac insufficiency have
disappeared & I had rather have this indi-
gestion than that

Tell Laura that I have purchased $29.25 28.75 29.5029.25 a fairly
good vicure rug from the edge of which she
can get a muff & tippet & have a light
warm & very pretty bed quilt for you, I
found one that had suited me much better for 33. 77/100
but for reasons too long to explain did not complete the
purchase. However as scarce as they are I am
well satisfied to have found that one. It was
what I most wanted, for & what will probably be
the best thing I can get. I say from the edge - because the
edge is long hair, like the Coat. L. has, the remainder
in shorter &, I think, prettier hair, - like the shortest
of her coat. Only the edge then would make a
good

On the whole however I know that
you both will be pleased with it.

July 17: We left Lima the morning of the 15,
I had a chance to return Mr Peet's call. Tell
Henry & Edward that he said “Bertie”- his son
- a rather fine boy in spite of his name-
was in Boston, doing well. Working as an elec-
trical engineer. The evening of the 14 to me took
tea - all of us at the Alcalde's - & I recognized
his sister in law as having been with Laura
on the trip to Oroya - in 1908. She - the sister-
in-law remembered her or said she did.

We are now as Salaverry - taking on Sugar
coffee, Matte (to be swetted elsewhere) & Co-
ca-leaves Of the latter there are about
40
4
40 bales - very valuable. We should have left
last night - Sunday - but there was a strike on
& all the workmen had gone to Truxillo to
attend a demonstration. They are loading
now like good fellows

There are two interesting men aboard & as I am
feeling entirely well - I was not going south - I can
talk to them. One an American from the Gug-
genheim Copper mines in Chile- an engineer
& one a Peruvian who was educated at Harvard
& is an Anthropologist. He is going up to Paita
to join a party sent by Mr Barbour - whom Laura knows & does not like - of Harvard which will
go from Paita Across to the Amazon, stu
to study some of the Indians en route-
both thos on this side of the Andes-Quichnas & A-
maras & the wild tribes beyond. The last is es-
pecially interesting, Indeed the Engineer
is also.

Gorgas was suffering from a bad cold yester-
day, but I think will be well today. I am comfor-
table since we reached Lima - except for

(July 18: We lay at Salaverry all day yesterday
leaving at 5.30. It was a bright day - & the clouds
did not obscure everything as it did when we
were there 8 days before. Just as we left the
view was beautiful, wonderfully beautiful.
The warm tan tints of the sand & the blacks &
dark browns of the mountains rising out of it
just behind the first br ridge - broken in many
places - rose a grey ridge of much higher
mountains - 10 to 12,000 feet I judge - w'h
caught the sunlight & glowed white, pale &
dark grey - with rose colored shadows on them
It
6
was simply beautiful, 6

We did not land, as it would, (or might) have
held us in quarantine in Panama. We did
land the previous trip - & cold & foggy & rough & dis-
aggreable it was. We went to the house of the A-
gent of Grace & Co. & ascended & discendinded in
a “Tina” - = bucket - from the wharf. Many
people from Truxillo - the town of with Salaverry
is the port came aboard Sunday & same
yesterday - They were mainly young women who
apparently come to see the ship - for a
Paseo - Some of them, in deed most of them
were pretty, quite pretty & we were sorry
that they got off.

I am infinitely better than on the downtrip in-
deed feel well & am enjoying the sea for the
first time since I left New York. She does roll
however when at Anchor.

I have written the report of the Commission which
will go to the Foundation & it has been made into No 6 to
6 copies & goes into the different members of the
commission
for confer-
ence today.
